instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used for analyzing the content of saturated fatty acids in edible oils?
Output: For analyzing the content of saturated fatty acids in edible oils,visible spectrum and near infrared reflectance spectrum of 7 edible vegetable oils were used. The range of the spectra measured was from 350 to 2,500 nm.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were employed for analyzing the content of saturated fatty acids in edible oils?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods employed for analyzing the content of saturated fatty acids in edible oils  include centralization, multiple scattering correction, standard normal variable transformation, and standardization.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the analysis models, and how well did this metric perform for analyzing the content of saturated fatty acids in edible oils?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the analysis models for analyzing the content of saturated fatty acids in edible oils was the determination coefficient of prediction set (R-P(2)) and the root mean square error of prediction set (RMSEp). 

The S2DCRN model obtained an R-P(2) value of 0.9879 and an RMSEp value of 0.5100 after pretreatment of the edible oil spectra. This indicates that the model had a high level of accuracy and precision in predicting the content of saturated fatty acids in the edible oils.

Furthermore, after selecting important wavelength spectra using a combination of RFrog and SFS, the S2DCRN model exhibited excellent performance with an R-P(2) value of 0.9679 and an RMSEp value of 0.4627. Although slightly worse than the results obtained using the full spectra, the number of wavelengths selected was less than 1% of the full spectra. This reduction in complexity while maintaining a high level of accuracy is beneficial for the development of portable and simplified detection devices.

Overall, the chosen metrics demonstrated that the S2DCRN model performed well in accurately and rapidly analyzing various fatty acids in edible vegetable oils using reflectance spectroscopy.

instruction: What machine learning models were compared with the novel two-dimensional spectral convolution regression network (S2DCRN) in the analysis of saturated fatty acids in edible oils using reflectance spectroscopy?
Output:
In the analysis of saturated fatty acids in edible oils using reflectance spectroscopy, the novel two-dimensional spectral convolution regression network (S2DCRN) was compared with the following machine learning models:

1. Full Convolutional Network (FCN)
2. Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR)
3. Support Vector Regression (SVR)
4. Random Forest (RF)

instruction: How does the performance of the novel two-dimensional spectral convolution regression network (S2DCRN) compare to traditional methods in analyzing the content of saturated fatty acids in edible oils using reflectance spectroscopy and machine learning?
Output:
The performance of the novel two-dimensional spectral convolution regression network (S2DCRN) was compared to traditional methods such as full convolutional network (FCN), partial least squares regression (PLSR), support vector regression (SVR), and random forest (RF) in analyzing the content of saturated fatty acids in edible oils using reflectance spectroscopy and machine learning.

The results showed that the S2DCRN obtained optimal performance after pretreatment of edible oil spectra, with a determination coefficient of prediction set (R-P(2)) of 0.9879 and a root mean square error of prediction set (RMSEp) of 0.5100. This indicates that the S2DCRN was able to accurately predict the content of saturated fatty acids in the edible oils.

Furthermore, when important wavelength spectra were selected using a combination of random frog (RFrog) and sequential forward selection (SFS), the S2DCRN exhibited excellent performance with a determination coefficient of prediction set (R-P(2)) of 0.9679 and a root mean square error of prediction set (RMSEp) of 0.4627.
